title: Senate report knocks State on Benghazi
content:
A bipartisan Senate report chastises the State Department for security failures leading up to the Sept. 11 assault in Benghazi — the second investigation in two weeks to fault Foggy Bottom for inadequate protections in Libya that led to the death of a U.S. ambassador .
The congressional probe also found that even though intelligence showed from the start that terrorists were responsible , the Obama administration was inconsistent in its public remarks about the nature of the assault , which “ contributed to the confusion in the public discourse after the attack about exactly what happened . ”
The 31-page report , released Monday and obtained early by ███ , was led by Sens . Joe Lieberman ( I-Conn. ) and Susan Collins ( R-Maine ) , the top members of the Homeland Security and Government Affairs Committee .
Collins said “ too often ” the State Department did not adequately respond to pleas for more security — such as more personnel — from officials at the diplomatic mission in Benghazi . Sometimes , requests for more security went ignored , according to Collins .
“ Our investigation found that the terrorists essentially walked right into the Benghazi compound unimpeded and set it ablaze , due to extremely poor security in a threat environment that was ‘ flashing red ’ in the words of a high-ranking official , ” Collins said in a statement .
The report found a “ large amount of evidence ” from intelligence officials that Benghazi was “ increasingly dangerous and unstable ” and that the risk of a “ significant attack ” against U.S. officials there was becoming “ much more likely. ” That information was shared with State Department officials , but no “ commensurate increase in security ” was granted , according to the report .
Classified intelligence indicated a “ rapidly deteriorating threat environment ” in Libya , which should have prodded officials in Washington to increase security levels there , the report found .
The diplomatic mission ’ s “ temporary ” status left it even more vulnerable to security failures , because it was difficult to establish standard procedures and secure adequate money for security upgrades , according to the report . And though it was “ widely ” known that Libyan officials were not capable of adequately protecting the mission in Benghazi , State Department officials did not fill that gap in security , the report found .

Senate Benghazi report knocks State

A bipartisan Senate report chastises the State Department for security failures leading up to the Sept. 11 assault in Benghazi — the second investigation in two weeks to fault Foggy Bottom for inadequate protections in Libya that led to the death of a U.S. ambassador.

The congressional probe also found that even though intelligence showed from the start that terrorists were responsible, the Obama administration was inconsistent in its public remarks about the nature of the assault, which “contributed to the confusion in the public discourse after the attack about exactly what happened.”

Story Continued Below

( Also on POLITICO: Obama: We’ve got “very good leads” on Benghazi)

The 31-page report, released Monday and obtained early by POLITICO, was led by Sens. Joe Lieberman (I-Conn.) and Susan Collins (R-Maine), the top members of the Homeland Security and Government Affairs Committee.

Collins said “too often” the State Department did not adequately respond to pleas for more security — such as more personnel — from officials at the diplomatic mission in Benghazi. Sometimes, requests for more security went ignored, according to Collins.

“Our investigation found that the terrorists essentially walked right into the Benghazi compound unimpeded and set it ablaze, due to extremely poor security in a threat environment that was ‘flashing red’ in the words of a high-ranking official,” Collins said in a statement.

The report found a “large amount of evidence” from intelligence officials that Benghazi was “increasingly dangerous and unstable” and that the risk of a “significant attack” against U.S. officials there was becoming “much more likely.” That information was shared with State Department officials, but no “commensurate increase in security” was granted, according to the report.

Classified intelligence indicated a “rapidly deteriorating threat environment” in Libya, which should have prodded officials in Washington to increase security levels there, the report found.

( Also on POLITICO: NBC reporter raises Hillary questions)

The diplomatic mission’s “temporary” status left it even more vulnerable to security failures, because it was difficult to establish standard procedures and secure adequate money for security upgrades, according to the report. And though it was “widely” known that Libyan officials were not capable of adequately protecting the mission in Benghazi, State Department officials did not fill that gap in security, the report found.
